div.p: ROVERE, or Roveredo, a ſtrong town of the Tyrol, on the confines of the republic of Venice; ſeated on the river Adige, at the foot of a mountain, and on the ſide of a ſtream, over which there is a bridge, defended by two large towers and a ſtrong caſtle, 1 o miles ſouth of Trent. The town is tolerably well built, and governed by a chief magiſtrate, ſtyled a Podeſat. There are ſeveral churches and cofivents, that contain nothing worthy of notice. The moſt remarkable thing, and what they call the great wonder oſ Roveredo, is its ſpinning-houſe for a manufacture of ſilk, in which they have a great trade here to the fairs of Bolzano. They have alſo a very good trade in wine Betwixt Trent and Roveredo is the ſtrong fort of Belem, belonging to the houſe of Auſtria. It is ſituated on a rock, and commands the roads at the foot of the mountain. E. Long. ιι. I. N. Lat. 46. 12.
